sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 950/17) against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a national of the United States of America, Mr M.T. (“the applicant”), on 20 December 2016. The Vice-President of the Section decided that the applicant’s name should not be disclosed (Rule 47 § 4 of the Rules of Court).
2.  The applicant was represented by Mr L. Drozdovskyy, a lawyer practising in Kyiv. The Ukrainian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.
3.   The applicant complained under Articles 6 and 8 of the Convention that the domestic courts had failed to establish his paternity restricting thereby his right of access to a court.
4.  On 20 March 2017 notice of the application was given to the Government.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1946 and currently lives in Berlin, Germany.
6.  In 2005 he was an English teacher in a school in Kyiv, Ukraine. At that time he entered into private relations with a married woman living in Kyiv. In 2006 the woman gave birth to a child. Her husband was indicated as the father in the child’s birth certificate. In 2007 a DNA test was performed proving that the applicant was in fact the father of the child. The applicant was not prevented from having access to the child by her mother, who accepted financial support from him on a monthly basis. The applicant bought a car for the child’s mother. In 2011 he wrote a will bequeathing all his property to the child.
7.  The applicant had regular contact with the child until 2015 when the mother informed the applicant that she had divorced her husband and that she had decided to marry a German national and move with the child to Germany. As the applicant opposed the decision to emigrate to Germany, the mother denied him access to the child and prevented him from communicating with the child.
8.  In June 2015 the applicant initiated proceedings before the Darnytskyy District Court of Kyiv (“the District Court”) seeking recognition of his paternity and to have the child’s birth certificate amended accordingly.
9.  During the hearing the mother of the child admitted that the applicant had provided regular financial support and had taken part in the upbringing and education of the child. However, she submitted that the applicant’s claims were time-barred under Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code, which provided a one-year time-limit for such claims (see paragraph 15 below). The applicant contended that he had delayed his lawsuit because he had not wished to disturb the child’s family situation and he had not been prevented from communicating with the child on a regular basis until 2015. Only when the child’s mother had decided to emigrate to another country with the child had he decided to seek formal recognition of his paternity.
10.  On 17 November 2015 the District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, declaring him the father of the child and ordering the amendment of the child’s birth certificate. The District Court considered that the applicant had missed the time-limit for valid reasons. It took into account the applicant’s argument that he had not wished to disturb the family and cause any harm to the child with a lawsuit during the long period when the mother had in fact assisted him in having regular access to the child.
11.  On 3 February 2016 the Kyiv Court of Appeal overturned the District Court’s decision and dismissed the applicant’s claim as time-barred. The appellate court stated that Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code provided a one-year time-limit, which had started to run from the moment the applicant had found out or should have found out about his paternity. The applicant had become aware of his paternity in 2007 when the DNA test had been performed (see paragraph 6 above); however he had applied to the court in 2015 (see paragraph 8 above), which had been too late.
12.  The applicant appealed on points of law, arguing that the Court of Appeal had applied the statute of limitations without duly taking into account the reasons for which he had delayed his action and without examining the child’s interests.
13.  On 13 July 2016 the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law, without examining whether the applicant had provided valid reasons which could justify his non-compliance with the time-limit set out in Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code.
II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
A.  Family Code of 10 January 2002
14.  Under Article 129 § 1 of the Family Code, an individual, who considers that he has fathered a child with a woman who is married to another man, is entitled to submit a claim against the woman’s husband to have his paternity recognised if the latter has been registered as the child’s father.
15.  Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code provides that the limitation period of one year applies to the claims for establishing paternity of a child and starts to run from the day when the claimant found out or should have found out about his paternity.
B.  Civil Code of 16 January 2003
16.  Article 267 § 5 of the Civil Code provides that if a court finds that the limitation period has been missed for a valid reason, the right violated should be subject to protection.

In 2005 he was an English teacher in a school in Kyiv, Ukraine. At that time he entered into private relations with a married woman living in Kyiv. In 2006 the woman gave birth to a child. Her husband was indicated as the father in the child’s birth certificate.

In 2011 he wrote a will bequeathing all his property to the child.

As the applicant opposed the decision to emigrate to Germany, the mother denied him access to the child and prevented him from communicating with the child.

In June 2015 the applicant initiated proceedings before the Darnytskyy District Court of Kyiv (“the District Court”) seeking recognition of his paternity and to have the child’s birth certificate amended accordingly.

During the hearing the mother of the child admitted that the applicant had provided regular financial support and had taken part in the upbringing and education of the child. However, she submitted that the applicant’s claims were time-barred under Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code, which provided a one-year time-limit for such claims (see paragraph 15 below).

The applicant contended that he had delayed his lawsuit because he had not wished to disturb the child’s family situation and he had not been prevented from communicating with the child on a regular basis until 2015.
Only when the child’s mother had decided to emigrate to another country with the child had he decided to seek formal recognition of his paternity.
On 17 November 2015 the District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, declaring him the father of the child and ordering the amendment of the child’s birth certificate.

On 3 February 2016 the Kyiv Court of Appeal overturned the District Court’s decision and dismissed the applicant’s claim as time-barred.

The appellate court stated that Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code provided a one-year time-limit, which had started to run from the moment the applicant had found out or should have found out about his paternity. The applicant had become aware of his paternity in 2007 when the DNA test had been performed (see paragraph 6 above); however he had applied to the court in 2015 (see paragraph 8 above), which had been too late.

The applicant appealed on points of law, arguing that the Court of Appeal had applied the statute of limitations without duly taking into account the reasons for which he had delayed his action and without examining the child’s interests.

On 13 July 2016 the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law, without examining whether the applicant had provided valid reasons which could justify his non-compliance with the time-limit set out in Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code.

events.source_text: Under Article 129 § 1 of the Family Code, an individual, who considers that he has fathered a child with a woman who is married to another man, is entitled to submit a claim against the woman’s husband to have his paternity recognised if the latter has been registered as the child’s father.

Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code provides that the limitation period of one year applies to the claims for establishing paternity of a child and starts to run from the day when the claimant found out or should have found out about his paternity.
Article 267 § 5 of the Civil Code provides that if a court finds that the limitation period has been missed for a valid reason, the right violated should be subject to protection.

The case originated in an application (no. 950/17) against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a national of the United States of America, Mr M.T. (“the applicant”), on 20 December 2016.
The Vice-President of the Section decided that the applicant’s name should not be disclosed (Rule 47 § 4 of the Rules of Court).
The applicant was represented by Mr L. Drozdovskyy, a lawyer practising in Kyiv.
The Ukrainian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.
The applicant complained under Articles 6 and 8 of the Convention that the domestic courts had failed to establish his paternity restricting thereby his right of access to a court.
On 20 March 2017 notice of the application was given to the Government.
In 2005 he was an English teacher in a school in Kyiv, Ukraine.
In 2006 the woman gave birth to a child.
In 2007 a DNA test was performed proving that the applicant was in fact the father of the child.
In 2011 he wrote a will bequeathing all his property to the child.
In 2015 the mother informed the applicant that she had divorced her husband and that she had decided to marry a German national and move with the child to Germany.

In June 2015 the applicant initiated proceedings before the Darnytskyy District Court of Kyiv (“the District Court”) seeking recognition of his paternity and to have the child’s birth certificate amended accordingly.
During the hearing the mother of the child admitted that the applicant had provided regular financial support and had taken part in the upbringing and education of the child.
On 17 November 2015 the District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, declaring him the father of the child and ordering the amendment of the child’s birth certificate.
On 3 February 2016 the Kyiv Court of Appeal overturned the District Court’s decision and dismissed the applicant’s claim as time-barred.

On 13 July 2016 the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law, without examining whether the applicant had provided valid reasons which could justify his non-compliance with the time-limit set out in Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code.

The case originated in an application (no. 950/17) against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by a national of the United States of America, Mr M.T. ("the applicant"), on 20 December 2016.
The applicant was represented by Mr L. Drozdovskyy, a lawyer practising in Kyiv.
The Ukrainian Government ("the Government") were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.
The applicant complained under Articles 6 and 8 of the Convention that the domestic courts had failed to establish his paternity restricting thereby his right of access to a court.
On 20 March 2017 notice of the application was given to the Government.
events.event: Notice of the application was given to the Government

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1946 and currently lives in Berlin, Germany.
events.event: Information about the applicant's personal details was provided
events.event_what: was born in 1946 and currently lives in Berlin, Germany

events.source_text: In 2005 he was an English teacher in a school in Kyiv, Ukraine.
events.event: The applicant worked as an English teacher

events.source_text: At that time he entered into private relations with a married woman living in Kyiv.
events.event: The applicant entered into private relations

events.source_text: In 2006 the woman gave birth to a child. Her husband was indicated as the father in the child’s birth certificate.
events.event: The woman gave birth to a child

events.source_text: In 2007 a DNA test was performed proving that the applicant was in fact the father of the child.
events.event_what: was proven to be the father of the child

events.source_text: The applicant was not prevented from having access to the child by her mother, who accepted financial support from him on a monthly basis.
events.event: The applicant had access to the child
events.event_what: was not prevented from having access

events.source_text: The applicant bought a car for the child’s mother.
In 2011 he wrote a will bequeathing all his property to the child.
events.event_what: wrote a will bequeathing all his property to the child

events.source_text: The applicant had regular contact with the child until 2015 when the mother informed the applicant that she had divorced her husband and that she had decided to marry a German national and move with the child to Germany.
events.event: The applicant's contact with the child was interrupted

events.source_text: As the applicant opposed the decision to emigrate to Germany, the mother denied him access to the child and prevented him from communicating with the child.
events.event: The applicant was denied access to the child

events.source_text: In June 2015 the applicant initiated proceedings before the Darnytskyy District Court of Kyiv ("the District Court") seeking recognition of his paternity and to have the child’s birth certificate amended accordingly.
events.event_what: initiated proceedings seeking recognition of his paternity...

events.source_text: During the hearing the mother of the child admitted that the applicant had provided regular financial support and had taken part in the upbringing and education of the child.
events.event: The mother admitted the applicant's involvement

events.source_text: However, she submitted that the applicant’s claims were time-barred under Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code, which provided a one-year time-limit for such claims (see paragraph 15 below).
events.event: The mother argued that the applicant's claims were time-barred

events.source_text: The applicant contended that he had delayed his lawsuit because he had not wished to disturb the child’s family situation and he had not been prevented from communicating with the child on a regular basis until 2015.
events.event: The applicant provided reasons for delaying the lawsuit

events.source_text: Only when the child’s mother had decided to emigrate to another country with the child had he decided to seek formal recognition of his paternity.
events.event: The applicant decided to seek formal recognition of his paternity

events.source_text: On 17 November 2015 the District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, declaring him the father of the child and ordering the amendment of the child’s birth certificate.
events.event: The District Court made a decision in favor of the applicant

events.source_text: On 3 February 2016 the Kyiv Court of Appeal overturned the District Court’s decision and dismissed the applicant’s claim as time-barred.
events.event: The Kyiv Court of Appeal overturned the District Court's decision

events.source_text: The applicant appealed on points of law, arguing that the Court of Appeal had applied the statute of limitations without duly taking into account the reasons for which he had delayed his action and without examining the child’s interests.

On 13 July 2016 the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law, without examining whether the applicant had provided valid reasons which could justify his non-compliance with the time-limit set out in Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code.
events.event: The Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court dismissed the applicant's appeal
events.event_who: Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court

events.source_text: II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
events.event: The relevant domestic law is presented

events.source_text: A.  Family Code of 10 January 2002
events.event: The Family Code of 10 January 2002 is presented

events.source_text: Under Article 129 § 1 of the Family Code, an individual, who considers that he has fathered a child with a woman who is married to another man, is entitled to submit a claim against the woman’s husband to have his paternity recognised if the latter has been registered as the child’s father.
events.event: The Family Code provides entitlement for paternity recognition
events.event_what: Under Article 129 § 1 of the Family Code...

events.source_text: Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code provides that the limitation period of one year applies to the claims for establishing paternity of a child and starts to run from the day when the claimant found out or should have found out about his paternity.
events.event: The Family Code sets a time limit for paternity claims

events.source_text: B.  Civil Code of 16 January 2003
events.event: The Civil Code of 16 January 2003 is presented

events.source_text: Article 267 § 5 of the Civil Code provides that if a court finds that the limitation period has been missed for a valid reason, the right violated should be subject to protection.
events.event: The Civil Code provides protection for rights violated due to missed limitation period

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event: The Court made a unanimous decision
events.event_what: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,

events.source_text: 1.   Declares the application admissible;
2.   Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: A violation of Article 8 of the Convention is held
events.event_what: Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;

events.source_text: 3.   Holds that there is no need to examine the complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention;
events.event: The complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention is not examined
events.event_what: Holds that there is no need to examine the complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention;

events.source_text: 4.   Holds

(a)  that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event: The respondent State is ordered to pay the applicant
events.event_what: (a)  that the respondent State is to pay...

events.source_text: (i)  EUR 4,500 (four thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
events.event: The respondent State is ordered to pay EUR 4,500 for non-pecuniary damage

events.source_text: (ii)  EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;
events.event: The respondent State is ordered to pay EUR 1,500 for costs and expenses

events.source_text: (b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: Simple interest is ordered to be paid on the above amounts
events.event_what: (b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months...

events.source_text: 5.   Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: The remainder of the applicant's claim for just satisfaction is dismissed
events.event_what: Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim...

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 19 March 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: The decision is made and notified
events.event_what: Done in English, and notified in writing...

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 950/17) against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a national of the United States of America, Mr M.T. (“the applicant”), on 20 December 2016.
The Vice-President of the Section decided that the applicant’s name should not be disclosed (Rule 47 § 4 of the Rules of Court).
events.event_what: decided that the applicant’s name should not be disclosed

events.source_text: The applicant complained under Articles 6 and 8 of the Convention that the domestic courts had failed to establish his paternity restricting thereby his right of access to a court.
events.event_what: complained under Articles 6 and 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: On 20 March 2017 notice of the application was given to the Government.
The applicant was born in 1946 and currently lives in Berlin, Germany.
In 2005 he was an English teacher in a school in Kyiv, Ukraine. At that time he entered into private relations with a married woman living in Kyiv.
In 2006 the woman gave birth to a child. Her husband was indicated as the father in the child’s birth certificate.
In 2007 a DNA test was performed proving that the applicant was in fact the father of the child.
The applicant was not prevented from having access to the child by her mother, who accepted financial support from him on a monthly basis.
The applicant bought a car for the child’s mother.
In 2011 he wrote a will bequeathing all his property to the child.

The applicant had regular contact with the child until 2015 when the mother informed the applicant that she had divorced her husband and that she had decided to marry a German national and move with the child to Germany.
As the applicant opposed the decision to emigrate to Germany, the mother denied him access to the child and prevented him from communicating with the child.

In June 2015 the applicant initiated proceedings before the Darnytskyy District Court of Kyiv (“the District Court”) seeking recognition of his paternity and to have the child’s birth certificate amended accordingly.
During the hearing the mother of the child admitted that the applicant had provided regular financial support and had taken part in the upbringing and education of the child.
However, she submitted that the applicant’s claims were time-barred under Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code, which provided a one-year time-limit for such claims (see paragraph 15 below).

The applicant contended that he had delayed his lawsuit because he had not wished to disturb the child’s family situation and he had not been prevented from communicating with the child on a regular basis until 2015.
Only when the child’s mother had decided to emigrate to another country with the child had he decided to seek formal recognition of his paternity.
On 17 November 2015 the District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, declaring him the father of the child and ordering the amendment of the child’s birth certificate.
The District Court considered that the applicant had missed the time-limit for valid reasons.

It took into account the applicant’s argument that he had not wished to disturb the family and cause any harm to the child with a lawsuit during the long period when the mother had in fact assisted him in having regular access to the child.
On 3 February 2016 the Kyiv Court of Appeal overturned the District Court’s decision and dismissed the applicant’s claim as time-barred.

The appellate court stated that Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code provided a one-year time-limit, which had started to run from the moment the applicant had found out or should have found out about his paternity.

The applicant had become aware of his paternity in 2007 when the DNA test had been performed (see paragraph 6 above); however he had applied to the court in 2015 (see paragraph 8 above), which had been too late.

The applicant appealed on points of law, arguing that the Court of Appeal had applied the statute of limitations without duly taking into account the reasons for which he had delayed his action and without examining the child’s interests.

On 13 July 2016 the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law, without examining whether the applicant had provided valid reasons which could justify his non-compliance with the time-limit set out in Article 129 § 2 of the Family Code.
events.event_who: Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
1. Declares the application admissible;
2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: held that there had been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: 3. Holds that there is no need to examine the complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention;
events.event_what: held that there was no need to examine the complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention

events.source_text: 4. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
i) EUR 4,500 (four thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
ii) EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;

b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
5. Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event_what: dismissed the remainder of the applicant’s claim

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1946 and currently lives in Berlin, Germany.

In 2005 he was an English teacher in a school in Kyiv, Ukraine. At that time he entered into private relations with a married woman living in Kyiv. In 2006 the woman gave birth to a child. Her husband was indicated as the father in the child’s birth certificate. In 2007 a DNA test was performed proving that the applicant was in fact the father of the child.

The applicant had regular contact with the child until 2015 when the mother informed the applicant that she had divorced her husband and that she had decided to marry a German national and move with the child to Germany. As the applicant opposed the decision to emigrate to Germany, the mother denied him access to the child and prevented him from communicating with the child.

In June 2015 the applicant initiated proceedings before the Darnytskyy District Court of Kyiv ("the District Court") seeking recognition of his paternity and to have the child’s birth certificate amended accordingly.
On 17 November 2015 the District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, declaring him the father of the child and ordering the amendment of the child’s birth certificate.
On 3 February 2016 the Kyiv Court of Appeal overturned the District Court’s decision and dismissed the applicant’s claim as time-barred.

The applicant appealed on points of law, arguing that the Court of Appeal had applied the statute of limitations without duly taking into account the reasons for which he had delayed his action and without examining the child’s interests.

On 13 July 2016 the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law, without examining whether the applicant had provided valid reasons which could justify his non-compliance with the time-limit set out in Article 129 µ1 of the Family Code.
events.event_who: Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court

events.source_text: Under Article 129 µ1 of the Family Code, an individual, who considers that he has fathered a child with a woman who is married to another man, is entitled to submit a claim against the woman’s husband to have his paternity recognised if the latter has been registered as the child’s father.

Article 129 µ2 of the Family Code provides that the limitation period of one year applies to the claims for establishing paternity of a child and starts to run from the day when the claimant found out or should have found out about his paternity.
Article 267 µ5 of the Civil Code provides that if a court finds that the limitation period has been missed for a valid reason, the right violated should be subject to protection.

FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Declares the application admissible; 2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; 3. Holds that there is no need to examine the complaint under Article 6 µ1 of the Convention; 4. Holds

The respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement: (i) EUR 4,500 (four thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage; (ii) EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;
Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
Done in English, and notified in writing on 19 March 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 µ2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
